Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 and the continuing jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court over custody and visitation matters.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 \u00a7 31.proposition: Plaintiff brings this Complaint pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 § 31 and all other applicable law seeking a modification of the Existing Order to eliminate the Wednesday overnight visitation and to adjust the alternate-weekend schedule to reflect the substantial change in circumstances described below.

Tropea v. Tropea, 398 Mass. 1 (1986) (es.raw_text: Tropea v. Tropea, 398 Mass. 1 (1986) (establishing principles for relocation and the burden of proof and best-interest analysis in custody/relocation matters).

Tropea v. Tropea, 398 Mass. 1 (1986) (es.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving assault with intent to kill, evidentiary issues, and prosecutorial argument. It does not address child custody, relocation, burdens of proof in custody matters, or best-interest analyses. The proposition cited (relocation principles in Tropea v. Tropea) plainly refers to a New York family law decision, not this Massachusetts criminal opinion, so this citation does not support the stated proposition.
Tropea v. Tropea, 398 Mass. 1 (1986) (es.relevant_excerpt: To determine whether the erroneous instruction created a substantial risk of a miscarriage of justice, we must evaluate the impact of the error in the context of the entire trial. In the performance of this task, we pay particular attention to those issues actively contested at trial... Because the erroneous instruction on specific intent to kill did not relate to an issue actively contested at trial, no substantial risk of a miscarriage of justice resulted from the erroneous portion of the jury charge.
